title: Games Inbox: How much do you play Fortnite?
text:
So I’m assuming Ghost Recon Breakpoint has been a flat out flop? It didn’t even get to number one, I never see anyone on my friends list playing it, and there generally seems to be no buzz around it. A bit like The Division 2, which makes me wonder whether the whole realistic military sim angle isn’t making a come back after all. But then the hype around Call Of Duty: Modern Warfare seems to be real, so that can’t be right.

Maybe it’s the whole microtransaction, buggy launch angle that’s put people off. If it is that it’s taken a while and there’s no obvious reason why it’d be now rather than later, but I’ll take it as a positive either way. I feel like these games as a service titles have reached a point now where there’s just too many and people just can’t keep up with them. And considering that’s 90% of what Ubisoft do now they’re essentially competing with themselves all the time.

Not having a go at them specifically but it’s weird that they’ve gone all in on games as a service and everyone else seems to have been a lot more cautious (which seems sensible). I’m curious to see whether they’ll take one for the team on this, and prove that the party’s over, or if they’ll just carry on regardless. I could do with there being a few less endless, half-broken-at-launch, games going into the next generation.

Hammeriron

GC: It doesn’t seem to have made much of a splash but it’s much too early to call it a flop. We know nothing about digital sales or how much money Ubisoft is making from it via microtransactions.
